title: Alexis Markowski is the best big in the B1G
text:
The question was, how good would she be in college against bigger and more experienced bigs?
News flash: she is the best (and the youngest).


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(wehoop)
library(gt)
library(cowplot)

playerbox <- load_wbb_player_box(
  seasons = 2022
) %>% separate(fg, into=c("FG", "FGA")) %>%
  separate(fg3, into=c("ThreesMade", "ThreesAttempted")) %>%
  mutate_at(3:17,as.numeric)

big <- c("Nebraska", "Iowa", "Nortwestern", "Minnesota", "Wisconsin", "Illinois", "Purdue", "Indiana", "Michigan", "Michigan State", "Ohio State", "Rutgers", "Penn State", "Maryland")

bigplayerbox <- playerbox %>%
  filter(athlete_position_abbreviation == "C" | athlete_position_abbreviation == "F") %>%
  filter(team_short_display_name %in% big) %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_short_display_name, athlete_position_abbreviation) %>%
  summarize( 
    minutes = sum(min),
    start = sum(starter),
    points = sum(pts),
    rebounds = sum(reb),
    blocks = sum(blk),
    fieldgoal = sum(FG),
    fieldgoalattempts = sum(FGA),
    threesmade = sum(ThreesMade),
    threesattempted = sum(ThreesAttempted)
    ) %>% 
  mutate(fgpct = fieldgoal/fieldgoalattempts, threepct = threesmade/threesattempted) 

alexis <- bigplayerbox %>% 
  filter(athlete_display_name == "Alexis Markowski")

bigbig <- bigplayerbox %>% 
  filter(threesattempted > 4) %>% 
  filter(fgpct > 0) %>% 
  rename(Athlete = athlete_display_name, Team= team_short_display_name) %>%
  select(Athlete, Team, fieldgoalattempts, fgpct, threesattempted, threepct) %>%
  arrange(desc(fgpct))

cumulativepoints <- playerbox %>% 
  filter(athlete_position_abbreviation == "C" | athlete_position_abbreviation == "F") %>%
  filter(team_short_display_name %in% big) %>%
  arrange(game_date) %>% 
  group_by(athlete_display_name) %>%
  mutate(TotalPoints = cumsum(pts)) 


alexiscumulative <- cumulativepoints %>% 
   filter(athlete_display_name == "Alexis Markowski")

ggplot() + 
  geom_step(data=cumulativepoints, aes(x=game_date, y=TotalPoints, group=athlete_display_name), color="gray") +
  geom_step(data=alexiscumulative, aes(x=game_date, y=TotalPoints, group=athlete_display_name), color="red", size=1.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept=as.Date("2022-01-04"), color="dark grey") + 
  geom_text(aes(x=as.Date("2022-01-16"), y=225, label="First career start"), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Date", 
    y="Points per game", 
    title="Where did Markowski start to shine?", 
    subtitle="The cold January weather made Alexis Markowski get hot.", 
    caption="By: Emme Pruitt  |  Source: wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )





Markowski was voted USBWA National Freshman of the Week on January 11, 2022 just one week after her standout game against No. 8 Michigan on January 4.
The true freshman’s first 20 point game of her career was against the No. 15 overall WNBA draft pick and All American Naz Hillman.
… After her first career start, it was only up from there.
But what about Nebraska? How did Markowski do in comparison to the rest of the Huskers?


Code
nebraska <- playerbox %>%
  filter(team_short_display_name == "Nebraska") %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_short_display_name, athlete_position_abbreviation) %>%
  summarize( 
    minutes = sum(min),
    start = sum(starter),
    points = sum(pts),
    rebounds = sum(reb),
    blocks = sum(blk),
    fieldgoal = sum(FG),
    fieldgoalattempts = sum(FGA),
    threesmade = sum(ThreesMade),
    threesattempted = sum(ThreesAttempted)
    ) %>% 
  mutate(fgpct = fieldgoal/fieldgoalattempts, threepct = threesmade/threesattempted) %>% 
  filter(minutes >= 250)

bar1 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nebraska, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, minutes), weight=minutes), fill="grey") + 
  geom_bar(data=alexis, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, minutes), weight=minutes), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(title="Nebraska vs. Markowski", 
       subtitle = "The 18 year old freshman appears on both lists, beating out senior Bella Cravens.",  
       x="", y="Total minutes played", 
       caption = "") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )


bar2 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nebraska, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, start), weight=start), fill="grey") + 
  geom_bar(data=alexis, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, start), weight=start), fill="red") +
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(title = "", 
       subtitle= "", 
       x="", y="Number of starts in the 2021-2022 season",  
       caption="") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )


bar3 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nebraska, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, rebounds), weight=rebounds), fill="grey") + 
  geom_bar(data=alexis, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, rebounds), weight=rebounds), fill="red") +
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(title = "", 
       subtitle= "", 
       x="", y="Total rebounds",  
       caption="") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )


bar4 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nebraska, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, blocks), weight=blocks), fill="grey") + 
  geom_bar(data=alexis, aes(x=reorder(athlete_display_name, blocks), weight=blocks), fill="red") +
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(title = "", 
       subtitle= "", 
       x="", y="Total blocks",  
       caption="Source: wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data | By Emme Pruitt") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )

plot_grid(bar1, bar2, bar3, bar4) 





Markowski led the Huskers in rebounds, was second in scoring, and was the new starter in the paint for Nebraska.
Now we have seen what Alexis Markowski has done for Nebraska, but what about compared to every forward and center in the Big Ten?


Code
bigbig %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  arrange(desc(threepct)) %>% 
  gt() %>% 
  cols_label(
    fgpct = "Shooting %",
    threepct = "Three pt %",
    fieldgoalattempts = "Shot attempts",
    threesattempted = "3 pt attempts"
  )%>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Alexis Markowski has more than just the green light from 3.",
    subtitle = "The sophomore center is at the top of a tough conference where it matters most."
  ) %>% tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) %>% tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )%>%
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Emme Pruitt  |  **Source:** wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data")
  )%>%
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) %>%
  opt_row_striping() %>% 
  opt_table_lines("none")%>%
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(fgpct, threepct),
    decimals = 1
  )%>%
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Athlete == "Alexis Markowski")
  )






  
    
      Alexis Markowski has more than just the green light from 3.
    
    
      The sophomore center is at the top of a tough conference where it matters most.

The conference leader in three point percentage and the Nebraska freshman record for threes. Alexis Markowski shot 10 percent better from three than every other forward and center in the Big Ten Conference. Impressive to say the least.
Shooting 50 percent from behind the arc as a guard is incredible. The average from three is 33.3 percent. Shooting 50 percent as a center is incredible.
To answer my own question: There is no doubt that Alexis Markowski was the best in the 2021-2022 season.
Leading her team in rebounds, leading the league in three point percentage, and dominating against house hold names, Markowski was voted Big Ten Freshman of the year, and recieved eight Big Ten Freshman of the Week awards.
This year, the stakes are high for Alexis. The reigning Big Ten Freshman of the Year is on the pursuit for Big Ten Player of the year, and even Naismith Player of the Year.
The scariest part for the Big Ten and anyone in Alexis Markowski’s way is that she has three. seasons. left.

title: What Nebraska women’s basketball team has been the best in the last decade?
text:
The 24-9 finish by Amy William’s team is the best finish by her staff at Nebraska since her hire in 2016, beating 4 teams that appeared in the Sweet Sixteen.
Is the 2021-2022 season statistically the best for Amy Williams in her time at Nebraska?
Let’s take a look at the data and compare her six seasons at Nebraska to some other big ten schools.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(wehoop)

teambox <- load_wbb_team_box( seasons = 2022:2016) %>% 
  separate(field_goals_made_field_goals_attempted, into=c("FG", "FGA")) %>%
  separate(three_point_field_goals_made_three_point_field_goals_attempted, into=c("ThreesMade", "ThreesAttempted")) %>%
  separate(free_throws_made_free_throws_attempted, into=c("FreeThrowsMade", "FreeThrowsAttempted")) %>% 
  mutate_at(12:35, as.numeric) %>% 
  group_by(team_short_display_name, season) %>% 
    summarize(
    FG = sum(FG),
    FGA = sum(FGA),
    Threes = sum(ThreesMade),
    ThreeAttempts = sum(ThreesAttempted),
    FTmakes = sum(FreeThrowsMade),
    FTattempts = sum(FreeThrowsAttempted),
    Rebounds = sum(total_rebounds),
    Oboards = sum(offensive_rebounds),
    Dboards = sum(defensive_rebounds),
    TeamBoards = sum(team_rebounds),
    Assists = sum(assists),
    Steals = sum(steals),
    Blocks = sum(blocks),
    TO = sum(turnovers),
    TeamTO = sum(team_turnovers),
    Fouls = sum(fouls)
    ) %>% 
   mutate(FGPCT = FG/FGA, ThreePCT = Threes/ThreeAttempts) 

big <- c("Nebraska", "Iowa", "Nortwestern", "Minnesota", "Wisconsin", "Illinois", "Purdue", "Indiana", "Michigan", "Michigan State", "Ohio State", "Rutgers", "Penn State", "Maryland")

bigteambox <- teambox %>%  
filter(team_short_display_name %in% big) %>%
  group_by(team_short_display_name) 

nebraska <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Nebraska")

illinois <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Illinois")

wisconsin <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Wisconsin")

maryland <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Maryland")

iowa <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Iowa")

rutgers <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Rutgers")

minnesota <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Minnesota")

indiana <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Indiana")

ohiost <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Ohio State")

michigan <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Michigan")

michiganst <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Michigan State")

pennst <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Penn State")

purdue <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Purdue")
nw <- bigteambox %>% 
   filter(team_short_display_name == "Northwestern")

average <- bigteambox %>% group_by(season) %>% summarise(mean_shooting=mean(FGPCT))

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=nebraska, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="red") +
  geom_line(data=illinois, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=iowa, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="yellow") +
  geom_line(data=indiana, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=purdue, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=wisconsin, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=michigan, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=michiganst, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=ohiost, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=pennst, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=minnesota, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=maryland, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=nw, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +  
  geom_line(data=rutgers, aes(x=season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=average, aes(x=season, y=mean_shooting), color="black") + 
  geom_text(aes(x=2019, y=0.44, label="Average Team FGPCT"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2021, y=0.52, label="Iowa"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2017, y=0.38, label="NU"), color="red") +
  labs(
    x="Date", 
    y="Field Goal %", 
    title="When has Nebraska shot it's best?", 
    subtitle="The Huskers have been stagnant since 2016", 
    caption="By: Emme Pruitt  |  Source: wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )





The Huskers field goal percentage in the last six seasons have all been below the big ten average.
For comparison, (and rivalry reasons) Iowa has led the big ten in this category. This could be credited to Iowa’s fifth year center Monika Czinano, who led the Big Ten Conference in shooting percentage.
Nebraska’s stellar shooting from beyond the arc last year was a hard one to stop for most teams.
How many assists and turnovers was Nebraska counting up each season? Could a lack of assists account to the field goal percentage?


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=bigteambox, aes(x=Assists, y=TO)) +
  geom_point(data=nebraska, aes(x=Assists, y=TO), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=550, y=463, label="'21-22"), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=447, y=525, label="'17-18"), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=374, y=360, label="'20-21"), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=589, y=330, label="Maryland '21-22"), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Assists", 
    y="Turnovers", 
    title="Which team had the best assist/turnover ratio?", 
    subtitle="William's 2021-2022 team had the most assists in her 6th season at Nebraska.", 
    caption="By: Emme Pruitt  |  Source: wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )





The scatterplot above details on the X axis assists and the Y axis turnovers. With Nebraska in red, they are definitely not a top team in turnovers. The 2021-2022 Nebraska team has the lowest number of assists and turnovers recorded. However, taking in account the limited number of games in the covid season, this might not be entirely true.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_step(data=bigteambox, aes(x=season, y=Oboards, group=team_short_display_name), color="gray") +
  geom_step(data=nebraska, aes(x=season, y=Oboards, group=team_short_display_name), color="red", size=1.0) +
  geom_step(data=maryland, aes(x=season, y=Oboards, group=team_short_display_name), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2016, y=340, label="Nebraska"), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2016, y=540, label="Maryland"), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Season", 
    y="Offensive Rebounds", 
    title="Did the addition of Markowski drastically increase NU's boards?", 
    subtitle="The Huskers 2021-2022 offensive rebounding skyrocketed with the addition of the Big Ten Freshman of the Year.", 
    caption="By: Emme Pruitt  |  Source: wehoop: The SportsDataverse's R Package for Women's Basketball Data") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )





Nebraska had the second most offensive rebounds in the Big Ten Conference last year, right behind Maryland.
The Huskers totaled 433 offensive rebounds in the 2021-2022 season, which is the most OBoards in William’s time at Nebraska. The second most offensive rebounds in Coach William’s time here is 404, in the years 2018-2019.
By looking at all of the data presented here, it is pretty clear to see that the 2021-2022 Husker squad is the best one that Amy Williams has had in her six years at Nebraska. Almost at the top of the conference in some cases (despite the FG percentage.)
The women’s team has been off to a bit shaky start this year, but only time will tell how the 2021-2022 season data compares to the 2022-2023 data. There is still a lot of basketball left to play.
But as of this moment, last years squad was the best Amy has had in a while.
